metadata.case_name: Rameshwar Lal Patwari v. State of Bihar

facts.text: Appellant applied under Art. 226 of the Constitution and S. 491 of CrPC for habeas corpus for release from detention in Bhagalpur Central Jail pursuant to order of Governor of Bihar dated July 4, 1967 under s. 3(1)(a)(iii) of Preventive Detention Act, 1950.
Appellant arrested on July 11, 1967 and served with grounds of detention on July 13, 1967.
Appellant made representation but release not recommended; High Court dismissed application on August 9, 1967.
Detention order recites necessity to prevent appellant from acting prejudicial to maintenance of supplies and services essential to community.

Ground 1: Appellant, prominent businessman of Dumka, associates with Mulchand Choudhury, Kanhaiaya Choudhury, Fulchand Modi, Pir Mohammad Bengaria and others in black-marketing foodgrains; has four trucks, one jeep, one car registered in relatives' names.

Truck No. BRL 1331 registered in brother-in-law's name (Harichandra Agarwala) caught on December 29, 1966 at Ranibahal near Mashanjor carrying 95 bags of paddy for illegal trade; case under Essential Commodities Act instituted; appellant on bail.
Appellant's trucks take wicked routes to Saithia, West Bengal; he pilots them.
Businessman of Barahiya disclosed appellant visited Barahiya several occasions, purchased gram, gramdal under various names, smuggled to West Bengal.

On night of 2-2-1966, raid by Magistrate R.S. Singh et al. on appellant's house found huge quantities of foodgrains; stock register irregular; no sale register produced (claimed with ITO); dealing without licence; case instituted, appellant on bail.
Appellant tried and acquitted in February 1967 in raid case, but grounds in July 1967 refer to it as pending.
Babu Ram Bikaneria of rice mill at Saitha, Birbhum WB visited Dumka on 26-11-1966, asked appellant to supply gram/gramdal; appellant promised.
On 7/8-12-1966, Mulchand Choudhury (agent) sent truck BRJ 2029 loaded with gram/gramdal to Saitha via Mahesh Kola checkpost.
Trucks BRL 1366 and van BRL 2005 found at Rameshwar on 7-12-1966, used to smuggle to WB.
Appellant purchases gram/gramdal through Gopal Mandal of Lakhisarai, Monghyr, smuggles to WB.
Advisory Board report dated 25-8-1967: grounds fairly particular and well-founded; material for detention in transport of foodgrains to WB; order not unreasonable.
Appellant denied ownership of truck BRL 1331 and paddy; paddy belonged to Prahlad Rai Giluka, cultivator, to be delivered at Dumka; notice from District Supply Officer admitted transport to Dumka.
Prahlad Rai Giluka confirmed paddy his, from his lands, to sell to appellant at Dumka; seized during loading at Ranibahal.

legal_issues.text: Whether grounds of detention are vague, indefinite, irrelevant or non-existing, depriving detenu of effective representation.
Scope of judicial review of preventive detention orders: sufficiency of grounds, subjective satisfaction, need for precise grounds.

petitioner_arguments.text: Some grounds did not exist in fact (e.g., acquitted case referred as pending), others vague or irrelevant.
Grounds do not afford real opportunity for representation; e.g., no specifics on routes, purchases; truck incident not smuggling as transport within Bihar.

respondent_arguments.text: Facts in para 4 (raid case) existed even after acquittal; prosecution failed but detenu knew and could represent.
Driver's statement shows truck belonged to appellant; no inquiry needed.

respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bhim Sen v. State of Punjab

court_reasoning.text: Courts not appellate authority on sufficiency of grounds or reasonableness of opinion; but grounds must not be vague/indefinite to allow representation; if vital ground non-existing, important.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Subjective satisfaction requires closest scrutiny; no room for avoidable errors.

court_reasoning.text: Ground 2 (wicked routes) vague: no specific instance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Detenu cannot effectively deny without particulars.

court_reasoning.text: Ground 3 (Barahiya purchases) vague: no names, dates.
Ground 4 (raid case) false: appellant acquitted Feb 1967, but grounds July 1967 call pending; shows carelessness.
Ground 1 vague except truck incident; truck to Dumka not WB smuggling; no inquiry into explanations.
Ground 5 vague: unclear 'he'; no reply to denials.
Two vague, one false, others defective; covers Shibban Lal: detention vitiated if grounds non-existing/illusory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Powers exercised with disregard for truth.

holdings.text: Detention order unsustainable where grounds vague, non-existing or illusory, vitiating subjective satisfaction.
Blackmarketing prejudicial to supplies; 'and' in s.3(1)(a)(iii) disjunctive.

precedents_cited.relevance: Detention vitiated if one ground non-existing/illusory; cannot assume surviving ground sufficient.

precedents_cited.case_name: Keshav Talpade v. The King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied in Shibban Lal; cannot substitute objective test for subjective satisfaction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhim Sen v. State of Punjab

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorizes detention to prevent prejudicial acts to supplies/services; grounds must be supplied; Advisory Board role.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Safeguards on arrest/detention; exception for preventive detention; habeas corpus.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Commodities Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Case instituted for illegal trade in foodgrains.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; detention order quashed due to defective grounds (vague, false, non-existing), vitiating the order.

key_quotes.text: "The detaining authority gave here two grounds for detaining the petitioner. We can neither decide whether these grounds are good or bad... this would vitiate the detention order as a whole."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Shibban Lal; crux of why non-existing grounds invalidate detention.

key_quotes.text: "It must require the closest scrutiny of the material on which the decision is formed, leaving no room for errors or at least avoidable errors."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes judicial scrutiny standard for preventive detention.

key_quotes.text: "This case displays both these defects and it is a matter of great regret that powers of detention without a trial... have been exercised... with such disregard for truth and accuracy."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's condemnation of detaining authority's carelessness.
